newsitem.title: USA: Signs of disease seen in Indiana soft winter wheat.
newsitem.headline: Signs of disease seen in Indiana soft winter wheat.

text.p: Indiana's soft red winter wheat crop is showing early signs of disease, and agronmoists fear that continued wet weather will hasten outbreaks and reduce yields, they said.

"We can see signs that the disease is present and if the weather conditions continue, it could be a problem," said Charles Mansfield, an agronomist for Purdue University in southwestern Indiana. "The potential is there, but it is driven mostly by environmental factors."
The emerging wheat crop in the southern part of the state was showing a higher-than-normal signs of disease inoculum, Mansfield said.
"The potential for disease is relatively high this year," Mansfield said.
Wet weather and flooding this winter have facilitated the development of disease in the soft red winter wheat crop, agronomists said.
More wet weather during the crop's growing season will leave the crop susceptible to disease like septoria glume blotch and powdery mildew, they said.
Mansfield said he has seen evidence of septoria glume blotch in southwestern areas of Indiana but not powdery mildew.
Septoria glume blotch affects the plant's foliage and leaves and ultimately reduces yields because it stunts growth, he said.
Wheat diseases generally do not manifest themselves until May or June, when the plant's head emerges and the grain starts to develop, Mansfield said.
Because the wheat crop in Ohio has just started to emerge, agronomists and crop observers there reported no signs of disease yet.
However, the wet winter weather has generated concern.
"Our wheat is just now greening up, and there's not much new tissue to get infected," said James Beuerlein, agronomist for Ohio State University.
But Beuerlein said the wet winter has also left the Ohio crop vulnerable to fusarium head scab and other fungal diseases if rainy conditions persist through the growing season.
"We're scared to death," Beurlein said. "There's no resistance, and no fungicides to combat it (head scab)."
The microorganism that causes head scab in wheat is also responsible for stalk rot in corn, and can be transmitted by wind, Beuerlein said.
"It (the microorganism) tends to be blowing around everywhere," Beuerlein said.
Head scab can reduce yields by up to 50 percent in some wheat varieties, Beuerlein said.
Evidence of disease in the Ohio soft red winter wheat crop will probably not be seen until later in the growing season, crop observers said.
"We're about three of four weeks away from critical disease spread," said Howard Siegrist, extension agronomist for Ohio State University in central Ohio.
